description: From Middle English enclosen, inclosen, from Middle English enclos, from Old French enclose, feminine plural past participle of enclore, from Vulgar Latin *inclaudō, *inclaudere, from Latin inclūdō (doublet of include), from in- (“in”) + claudō (“to shut”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kleh₂u- (“key, hook, nail”). Equivalent to en- +‎ close.

verbs.description: enclose (third-person singular simple present encloses, present participle enclosing, simple past and past participle enclosed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to surround with a wall, fence, etc.
(transitive) to insert into a container, usually an envelope or package
examples: Please enclose a stamped self-addressed envelope if you require a reply.
